Posts.Content: Hi Dorothee.  Good luck for the race.  Hope it all goes well. Do you have one of those charity pages where we might be able to make a donation?
Posts.Title: How would money help?

Posts.Content: Hi Angela.  This must be very confusing for you.  Sorry I can't offer any help with this particular problem, other than I hope you get to the bottom of it soon and make sure you are being given the correct chemo drugs. I did wonder, however, how often mistakes could be made on letters or reports due a typing error, bearing in mind, in your case, the - & + keys are next to each other on the keyboard. I thought if sometimes people like yourself may have extra worry about treatments and diagnosis from what may be a simple mistake, but in the medical order of things the implications could be huge and make a big difference to a person's treatment and wellbeing. Hope you get it sorted out soon  Best wishes.
Posts.Title: ER+ and ER- - two tests, two different results.Anyone else?

Posts.Content: Hi Helen.  So pleased you got this checked out.  At least now you will feel a little bit relieved knowing what was causing the dizzy spells.  Try to get as much rest as you can.  I'm going for my surgery next week so, even though I usually drink a lot, I will make sure to drink even more now just to be on the safe side. Big hugs xx
Posts.Title: Op

Posts.Content: Helen, since you have several problems as well as your recent op, have you thought of ringing the Occupational Therapy team at your hospital for some practical help with your bathing difficulties.  I know you said you are having a walk in shower installed but maybe, in the meantime, they could help provide you with some bathing aids to help you get in the bath.  After a fall last year they helped me a lot and I got a board and stool provided which helped enormously and they let me have them without any charge.  It's worth a try.  Wishing you well. x
Posts.Title: Op

Posts.Content: Hi Binny My ER+ number was 8.8 and, as I understand it from the way it was explained to me, this was a very good reading.  It meant that the cells would be very responsive to the drug treatment.  Hope this helps. Big Hugs x
Posts.Title: ER Positive... what does the number mean.??

Posts.Content: Quite right too allme.  You go for it.
Posts.Title: Embarrassing Nipple Moment

Posts.Content: Hi Nickyslin and Kate I agree with Judith's comment regarding Daktarin gel.  I was prescribed this by my oral surgeon last year when I was having terrible problems with my mouth and tongue as a side effect of one of my heart medicines.  My mouth was in quite a bad ulcerated state at the time and did have a burnt appearance but this gel, although very sticky and sugary, used at night did make a big difference. I was also given lidocaine lollipops, to keep in the fridge, for use through the day which were very soothing although wouldn't help much with taste problems as they taste quite odd. I hope you both get it sorted out soon as it is very difficult when you can't eat comfortably on top of everything else. Kind regards and Hugs.
Posts.Title: Mouth problems

Posts.Content: Thank you for that Kate.  I did wish the ground would open up and swallow me, at the time. They were the  very large sized cod liver oil capsules, probably the one a day version, by the look of them.  Maybe I should have swallowed them when I got home, they might've helped oil my joints. Even worse, I forgot to remove them straight away and didn't realize until a couple of hours after I got home.  We'd already stopped at a shop on the way home and had visitors when I got back. Nevermind.  At least I will know if I ever need to have one again and, also, so will any other ladies who are due to go for a scan, after reading this. Best Wishes
Posts.Title: Embarrassing Nipple Moment

Posts.Content: Hi everyone.  Yesterday I went for my MRI scan and I would like to nominate myself for the 'Silly question of the week' Award. While I was waiting in the cubicle in my little hospital gown the lovely Radiographer came in with a bottle of capsules, to see if I was ready.  She said, holding one of them in her hand, "we need to to put one of these on your nipples"  "Really", said I, whilst trying to imagine how they would fit and what would happen to the oil, "so do I just snap them in half and use one on each side" "Nooo" she smiled, "You get two, one for each side".  She then produced a roll of tape and handed me two pieces and said "Just tape one over each nipple, we use them as a guideline to line you up in the machine and so we know where we are when the dye goes in" I felt so stupid but this lovely lady did not split her sides or fall about laughing, though she could quite easily have done and I wouldn'tve blamed her. Anyway, all of the staff were brilliant with me and so helpful, especially when it came to getting me on the board and into the machine.  I'm still sore around the ribs and my arms aren't moving so well but I'm so pleased that it's done.  Now I can just hope that the result is of the better kind as my type of surgery is dependant upon this. Best wishes to all xx
Posts.Title: Embarrassing Nipple Moment

Posts.Content: Hi everyone.  Having just been diagnosed a week ago, please forgive me not knowing the correct procedures here as I am new to it and not a natural posting messages sort of person.  When my consultant told me the news last week he gave me some guidelines on what my treatment will be, indicating that I will need WLE surgery (hopefully) followed by radiotherapy and then five years of Tamoxifen.  My concern is that I have suffered from severe chronic FM Syndrome for many years and also, following a fall last year, was diagnosed with Osteoporosis so I also have treatments for my bones. I am very worried about how I will be affected by the side effects of Tamoxifen as the list mimics most of the problems I have already experienced with the fibromyalgia and I don't know if I could tolerate doubled up pain etc.  I also read a couple of brief articles that suggest I may not be able to take my regular medicines while using Tamoxifen. Obviously, I will follow the doctor's treatment plan as getting rid of the cancer is now priority and I will cope the best way I can but I haven't been able to find out much about managing this type of treatment combined with regular meds for other illnesses. Does anyone have these conditions or anything similar who can give me some advice regarding my next steps forward?
Posts.Title: Help needed - B C treatments Rad and Tamoxifen side effects with Fibromyalgia...

Posts.Content: Hi Flower.  Thank you very much for your reply.  It has helped a lot to hear of your own experience in circumstances very similar to my own.  You are right, of course that the departments should be able to figure out my medicines between each other and I will happily try whatever they decide on.  I'm due to see my Rheumatologist soon so by then he should have received this newest information from my notes. I hope I didn't come across as some sort of wimp when I posted my question.  I'm actually a very practical person and one of life's natural fighters but like all of you ladies I'm suddenly  finding myself in uncertain times. I agree some of the websites can throw out some scary, and occasionally downright weird stuff but you have no need to worry on that score.  I avoid most of it.  I stick to a  couple of trusted UK sites for any info I need and this has worked well for me over the past couple of years.  The stuff I read about Tamoxifen I found from the drug company website. Interestingly enough this is the site where I have obtained all of my recent information over the past few weeks.  Any stuff I have googled always brings up this one at the top of the page, thankfully. My next challenge is a purely practical one - How to fit me into the MRI machine next week. Thank you for your help.  Hugs to you tooxx
Posts.Title: Help needed - B C treatments Rad and Tamoxifen side effects with Fibromyalgia...

Posts.Content: Thank you Kate for taking the time to reply to me. As I said to Flower, it means a lot to me.  I am sure now that when I go back for my next appointment I will be better prepared to ask any questions about forthcoming treatments and I can see that they must have to tailor everyone's needs to the individual whilst still following the path of whatever may be necessary. I do feel much better about it now though.  Thank you again.
Posts.Title: Help needed - B C treatments Rad and Tamoxifen side effects with Fibromyalgia...

Posts.Content: Binny, you poor things.  I'm so sorry this has happened to you and your husband. Honestly, I'm shocked.  Such treatment in your circumstances seems incredibly harsh of them.  You are quite right, of course, to them it would be all about the money, nevermind the fact that it was your home.  I hope you did finally mange to settle down and get some rest from it at last. From what you've said about travel insurance and the ridiculously bumped up cost, I may as well give up on the idea of Life insurance. Hugs to you. x
Posts.Title: borrowing money

Posts.Content: Hi Aroma mum I found your question very interesting because I was thinking of something very similar just a couple of days ago.  I don't know how the mortgage or loans situation would work, obviously I should think it would affect it in some way.  I was thinking how would we be affected by applying for Life Insurance.  This was something I was considering a couple of months ago, I had even got some quotes but not got around to taking any of them further when I was diagnosed.  It just suddenly occurred to me that the position would now be different and the quotes will probably be way off. Maybe someone could answer both our queries. Kind regards and Hugs x
Posts.Title: borrowing money

Posts.Content: Hi everyone. It is now 11 days since my surgery, WLE & Sentinel nodes, and today was my results day. I just wanted to share my very good news.  My surgeon was very pleased with the results.  The cancer was very small and it has all been removed. He also said that he had removed 7 lymph nodes and they were all clear.   As you will all understand I am feeling a lot more relieved and happy tonight than I did this time last night.  Even though I have had a very good team and they were all brilliant and even though the Consultant had told me that they were quite confident of a good result, until the actual lab results are through and they tell you officially, there is still that niggly feeling of doubt. I'm now full of optimism and ready for the next stage of battle, keeping things this way.  I shall plod along until I get my oncology appointment then be ready for the radiotherapy. Sorry if I'm waffling on again but I'm so pleased to be rid of the little parasite and I don't want any of it's little friends choosing to lodge with me again. Kinds regards & Best Wishes & Big Hugs to you all x
Posts.Title: My Good News

Posts.Content: Hi Binny Please don't apologise for your negative mood.  The waiting times are very stressful and it's understandable that you will worry more if your appointments are due around Christmastime.  My consultant said that I will be put onto six monthly check ups and annual scans so mine will be hitting around the January time, I guess.  He did say they would do mammograms and ultrasounds at these appointments so I suppose they will compare the newer ones to the last ones to look for any changes, if that helps at all. As for exhaustion and insomnia I think all of us on here will be suffering from those so you seem quite normal in that respect.  I've been trying out Mindfulness after I read a magazine article about it and I've found it very helpful just focussing on one thing and forgetting everything else. I've also been doing a lot of deep breathing about every hour, which I've found to be of huge benefit.  It's good just closing your eyes and thinking of nothing for a minute or two. Maybe some of the other ladies can give you more info about the appointments than I can which will help you nearer the time. Hope your mood lifts a little soon.  Sending you good vibes and Big Hugs xx
Posts.Title: My Good News

Posts.Content: Thank you Sue Good luck with your chemo sessions.  Luckily I don't need to have them so I will have time to heal a bit before the radiotherapy starts. Big Hugs  xx
Posts.Title: My Good News

Posts.Content: Hi Molly I was told by my Oncologist that Letrozole was a newer drug and had very good results regarding less re-occurernce stats. over five years.  He told me that normally it would've been the first choice for me but unfortunately, because I have Osteoporosis, it had been decided between him and my surgeon that it would not be suitable because of a side effect of weakening bones and therefore they would give me Tamoxifen instead. The other main side effect is the hair loss but this is also a side effect of Tamoxifen as well. Hope this helps. Kind regards
Posts.Title: side effects of letrozol

Posts.Content: Hi again Maggie I think it's only natural to be feeling a bit lost and all at sea at the stage you are at now.  Sounds to me a bit like going from a roller coaster to a gentle rowing boat.  I expect a lot of people would feel like that. As for your appointment, I can fully understand why you would find the experience confusing, sepecially seeing a different doctor and different team.  I would make sure that you tick the box for copies of the reports or letters to be sent to you and then to read through them afterwards very carefully so that if anything doesn't make sense ,or sounds different to the way you remember it, at least you can then discuss it with your nurse or GP. More Hugs x
Posts.Title: in limbo
